creditline: The David and Margaret Christenson Endowment for Art Acquisition
description: paper collage with printed photographs, fragments of text, Bingo cards, playing cards, cigar bands and cancelled stamps; some painted elements around stamps at top and behind two standing figures in lower quadrants; overall composition with stamps in background grid at top; playing cards and Bingo cards around edges and five vertical figures (three human figures and two fish) above figures at bottom; head and shoulders of a woman wearing a uniform and a sailor's hat with a pipe between her teeth at center; "THE PRIVATE LIFE OF THE GOD" at top center; "THE AMERICAN SYSTEM" at bottom center
image_copyright: © Estate of Felipe Jesus Consalvos%2C Courtesy Fleisher Ollman Gallery
medium: Collage of found printed images and text, photographs, cigar bands, postage stamps, and pigments on paper
text:
An artist and self-appointed healer, Felipe Jesus Consalvos earned his living, for most of his life, as a cigar roller. Over the course of his lifetime, he extrapolated the vernacular tradition of cigar band collage to a sophisticated practice. His obsessive body of work (which range from works on paper to musical instruments and furniture) was discovered in 1980 at a West Philadelphia garage sale.
The Havana-born artist immigrated to Miami around 1920, eventually settling in Philadelphia. Consalvos' work was often playful and subversively political in tone. Begun in the 1920’s, his collages incorporate phrases that comment on racial and sexual difference and evince a deep dislike for George Washington, who almost always appears in drag.
title: The American System
